comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A root in the census shows two Edith Coles'eses in 1901, and none at all in 1911. One Edith was 1 month old in 1901, so that's not her. This one (a .pdf) was only eight, so would be 17 in 1910. CofE, born in Cornwall, living in Cove, near Kinsale in 1901. Her Dad was gone in 1911, too, maybe they moved back to England. So is this that Edith? Or is it some furriner actress who was just visiting?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: This is only eBay, so not a permanent link, but it's a postcard of Edith Coles "The Worst Woman in London".

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I was thinking furriner, but maybe not. And wow, wonder if that was a character assessment, or was it a character she played in the theatre... Added it as a tag either way.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From Memories of Show Business by Percy G Court, 1953: Miss Edith Cole had her usual benefit on Friday night of each visit - ah -hem "The Still Alarm" with its two white horses which harnessed themselves to the engine and drove off the stage with fire bells clanging.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A playbill from Leeds, 1909: Monday, 17th May, 1909. This evening's entertainment consists of the 'special engagement of W.W. Kelly's London Company, including the celebrated actress Miss Edith Coles, in the most successful historical play of the century' called, 'A Royal Divorce', by W.G. Wills. So, if she was a headliner in 1909, I don't think she was our Kinsale girl, she'd only be 16 in 1909.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The Era (London) June 29th 1895: CORK OPERA HOUSE - Manager, Mr John Horgan - Mr W. W. Kelly's company paid us a return visit on Monday in A Royal Divorce. Miss Edith Coles as the Empress Josephine acted with great delicacy. As Napoleon Mr J. H. Clyndes did well. Mr H. Gray Dolby was good as Talleyrand. In May 1896 the same company and cast were due to perform A Royal Divorce at The Standard Theatre, London. In March 1895 they had performed A Royal Divorce for three nights at the Prince's Theatre, Bristol.

comment._content: Ancestry.co.uk - 1911 census, St Pancras, London Violet Edith COLE, Head, 27, single, Actress, worker, born in Westminster. Maud Emily CATLING, visitor, 27, single, Actress, worker, born in Windsor Signature George R Foss, 1 Doughty Street. theatricalia.com/person/bng/george-r-foss This must be a different Edith COLE www.freebmd.org.uk Marriage September quarter 1898, Hackney, London Edith Julia COLE William Wallace KELLY 1901 census, 8 Hamilton Square, Birkenhead, Cheshire William W KELLY, Head, 47, Manager Theatrical, Employer, born in United States Mrs KELLY (Edith COLE), Wife, 39, Actress, Own Account, born in Middlesex London Julia COLE, visitor, married, 58, born in Middlesex London
